In determining risk of harm posed by a chemical storage facility under subparagraph (A), the

text.#text: The term

Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this part, the Administrator or each  State
			 exercising primary enforcement responsibility for public water systems, as
			 applicable, shall carry out, directly or through delegation, a chemical
			 storage facility source water protection program   to provide for the
			 protection of public water systems from a release of a chemical from a
			 covered chemical storage facility.

A State program under subsection (a) shall provide for oversight and inspection of each covered 
			 chemical storage facility in accordance with the requirements described in
			 paragraph (2) to prevent the release of chemicals into the water supply in
			 watersheds with public water systems that rely on surface water, including
			 a covered chemical storage facility located in a source water area 
			 identified under section 1453.
At a minimum, a State program shall include—
requirements for covered chemical storage facilities, including—
acceptable standards of good design, construction, or maintenance;
leak detection;
spill and overfill control;
inventory control;
an emergency response and communication plan;
an employee training and safety plan;
an inspection of the integrity of each covered chemical storage facility;
lifecycle maintenance, including corrosion protection;
notice to the Administrator, the appropriate State agency, and applicable public water systems of—
the potential toxicity of the stored chemicals to humans and the environment; and

safeguards or other precautions that can be taken to detect, mitigate, or otherwise limit the
			 adverse effects of a release of the stored chemicals; and

financial responsibility requirements, including proof of insurance, bond, or other similar
			 instrument;
inspections of covered chemical storage facilities, which shall occur—

for a covered chemical storage facility identified in a source water assessment area under section
			 1453, not less frequently than once every 3 years; and
for any other covered chemical storage facility, not less frequently than once every 5 years; and
a comprehensive inventory of the covered chemical storage facilities  in each State.

For purposes of primary enforcement responsibility,  a State program and any requirements under
			 this part shall be—

considered to be a part of the national primary drinking water regulations established under
			 section 1412; and
implemented and enforced in accordance with the procedures under sections 1413 and 1414 and part E.
A State program shall be carried out—

if the State exercises	primary enforcement responsibility for public water systems in that State
			 under this Act, by the State; and

if the State does not exercise primary enforcement responsibility for public water systems in that
			 State under this Act, by the Administrator.

The Administrator may issue guidance or provide other technical assistance to State programs in
			 carrying out activities under this part.

The Administrator under section 1472(d)(2) or the State under section 1472(d)(1), as applicable, 
			 may issue an order to the owner or operator of a covered chemical storage
			 facility to carry out this part.

If costs have been incurred by the Administrator or the State, as applicable, for undertaking a
			 response action under this part relating to the release of a chemical, the
			 owner or operator of the covered chemical storage facility shall be liable
			 to the Administrator or the State for those costs.

Notwithstanding the inspection schedule under section 1472(b)(2)(B), no person shall transfer a
			 covered chemical storage facility unless—

header.#text: Transfer of covered chemical storage facilities

text.#text:
prior to the closing or completion of the transfer, the transferor submits to the transferee the
			 results of a pretransfer inspection of the integrity of the covered
			 chemical storage facility, which shall be conducted pursuant to any
			 requirements set by the Administrator under section 1472(d)(2) or the
			 State under section 1472(d)(1), as applicable; and

the transferor or the transferee agrees to take appropriate measures to address the results of the
			 pretransfer inspection prior to the date that is 30 days after the date on
			 which the covered chemical storage facility closes or is transferred.

The Administrator or State, as applicable, shall provide  public water systems with information
			 relating to—

emergency response plans for covered chemical storage facilities located within the same watershed
			 as the public water system; and

an inventory of each chemical held at the covered chemical storage facilities described in 
			 paragraph  (1).
A copy of each	emergency response plan submitted under section 1472(b)(2)(A) shall be provided to—

the Administrator (if the State exercises primary responsibility for public water systems in that
			 State); and
the Secretary of Homeland Security.

The Administrator or a State, as applicable, may keep confidential information the Administrator or
			 the State  determines to be sensitive and present a security risk to a
			 covered chemical storage facility.
Paragraph (1) shall not—
apply to public health information; or

prevent the sharing of information with the Administrator, the Secretary of Homeland Security, a
			 public water system, or a public agency involved in emergency response.
